projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: ARTICLES OF Peace, Union and Confederation, Concluded and Agreed between his Highne≈øs OLIVER Lord PROTECTOR Of the Common-wealth of ENGLAND, SCOTLAND & IRELAND, and the Dominions thereto belonging.
And the Lords the STATES GENERAL of the United Provinces of the NETHERLANDS.
„Äà1 line„Äâ Old Style, in the year of our Lord God, 1654.

p.hi: Printed and Publi≈øhed by his Highne≈øs special „Äà‚óä„Äâ .

div.p: London, Printed by William du-Gard and Henry Hills, Printers to His Highne≈øs the Lord Protector, 1654.

div.head: ARTICLES OF THE PEACE.
div.p:
I. IT is agreed, concluded, and accorded, That from this day forward there ≈øhall be a true, firm and inviolable Peace, more ≈øincere Friend≈øhip, and nearer Alliance, Union and Confederation than heretofore, betwixt the Common-wealth of England, and the States General of the United Provinces of the Netherlands, and the
re≈øpective Lands, Countries and Cities, without di≈øtinction of Places, under their obedience, and the people and inhahitants of them, re≈øpectively of what quality and condition ≈øoever they be.

II. Item, Agreed, That from henceforth all Enmity, Ho≈øtility, Di≈øcord, and War betwixt the ≈øaid two Commonwealths, their People and Subjects, ≈øhall cea≈øe, and each party ≈øhall hereafter ab≈øtain from all Offences, Spoils, Depredations, and Injuries by Sea, Land and Fre≈øh-waters in all their re≈øpective Lands, Countries, Dominions, Places, or Governments what≈øoever.

III. Item, That all Offences, Injuries, Charges and Dammages, which either party hath ≈øu≈øtained by the other ≈øince the „Äà‚óä„Äâ of May, in the year one thou≈øand ≈øix hundred fifty two, ≈øhall be taken away and forgotten in ≈øuch manner as that hereafter neither party ≈øhall pretend any maner again≈øt the other for or upon occa≈øion of any the afore≈øaid Offences, Injuries, Charges and Dammages; But that there ≈øhall be a perfect abolition of all and every of them untill this pre≈øent day. And all actions for the ≈øame ≈øhall be held and reputed void and null.
IV. That all Pri≈øoners of both ≈øides of what Condition, or in what≈øoever Place they be, ≈øhall be ≈øet at liberty, without ran≈øom or con≈øideration given for them.

V. That the two Common wealths ≈øhall remain confederate friends, joyned and allyed together for the Defence and Pre≈øervation of the Liberties and Freedom of the People of each again≈øt all whom≈øoever, who ≈øhall attempt the Di≈øturbance of either State by Sea or Land, or be declared Enemies to the Freedom and Liberty of the People living under either of the ≈øaid Governments.

VI. That neither of the Common-wealths ≈øhall make. do. art. treat of, or attempt any thing again≈øt the other, or the People of either, in any place either at Land or Sea, or in any the Havens, Creeks, Precincts, or Fre≈øh-waters of either, upon any occa≈øion what≈øoever. Nor that either of them, or the People of either give, yield, or afford any aid, coun≈øel, favour, or a≈ø≈øent that any thing ≈øhall be done, treated of, or attempted by any other whom≈øoever, to the injury and wrong of the other, or the People of either, but ≈øhall expre≈øly and with effect contradict, gain≈øay, oppo≈øe, and really hinder an whom≈øoever abiding or dwelling within either of the Common-wealths re≈øpectively, who ≈øhall be under their power that art, do, treat of, or attempt any thing again≈øt either of the Common-wealths.

VII. That neither of the Common-wealths, or the People abiding, inhabiting, or dwelling within either of them re≈øpectively, or within their power, ≈øhall yield give, or afford any aid coun≈øel or favour to the Enemies or Rebells of either, but ≈øhall expre≈øly really and with effect hinder any inhabiting, dwelling or abiding within either of them or within their power, from giving any aid or a≈ø≈øi≈øtance unto ≈øuch Enemies or Rebells, by Men, Shipping, Arms, Ammunition, Money, Uictuals, or otherwi≈øe by Sea or Land; and all ≈øuch ≈øhips, Arms, Ammunition, Money, Goods, or Uictuals, of or belonging to any per≈øon or per≈øons what≈øoever, that ≈øhall be provided, employed, or made u≈øe of, contrary to the intent of this Article, ≈øhall be confi≈øcate and forfeited to the re≈øpective Common-wealths. And the per≈øon or per≈øons who ≈øhall wittingly and willingly do, attempt, coun≈øel, or be employed therein, ≈øhall be declared Enemies to both Common-wealths, and ≈øhall ≈øuffer the pains and penalties of Trea≈øon within the Common-wealth where the Offence ≈øhall be committed. And to the end there may be a ≈øpecification made of what Goods ≈øhall be deemed, prohibit, or contraband, Commi≈ø≈øioners may in convenient time be appointed to determine herein Provided in the mean time that this extend not to the impeachment of any thing contained in the pre≈øent Article.

VIII. That the two Common-wealths ≈øhall truly and ≈øincerely a≈ø≈øi≈øt each other, as need ≈øhall require, again≈øt the Rebells and Enemies of either, at Sea and Land, with Men & Ships, at the Co≈øts and Expences of the party requiring the ≈øame, in ≈øuch proportion and manner and upon ≈øuch Terms and Conditions as the two States ≈øhall agree, and the pre≈øent occa≈øion require.

IX. That neither of the Common-wealths, or the People of either ≈øhall receive into any of their Iurisdictions, Countries, Lands, Ports, Creeks, or Precincts, any per≈øon or per≈øons, that art or ≈øhall be declared by either of the Common wealths to be Enemies, Rebells or Fugitives of the other; Nor ≈øhall give, yield or afford to any ≈øuch declared Enemy, Rebell or Fugitive within the places afore≈øaid, or other-where, though out of their Territories, Countries, Lands, Ports, Creeks, or Precincts, any aid, coun≈øel, Lodging, Entertainment, Souldiers, Ships, Money, Arms, Ammunition or Uictuals. Nor ≈øhall either of the States permit ≈øuch Enemies, Rebells or Fugitives to be received by any per≈øon or per≈øons what≈øoever into their Iurisdictions, Countries, Lands. Ports, Creeks, or Precincts, nor ≈øhall ≈øuffer any Aid, Coun≈øel, Lodging, Entertainment, Souldiers, Ships, Money, Arms, Ammunition, or Uictuals to be given, yielded or afforded
unto ≈øuch Enemies. Rebels or Fugitives, but ≈øhall expre≈øly and effectually oppo≈øe, with≈øtand, and really hinder the ≈øame.

X. Item, It is agreed, That it either of the ≈øaid Common-wealths ≈øhall by their publique and Authentick-Letters, give notice, ≈øignify, or declare to the other Common wealth any per≈øon or per≈øons, to be, and have been their Enemie or Enemies, Rebel or Rebels, Fugitive or Fugitives, and that they are, or re≈øide within the others Iurisdictions, Territories, Dominions, Lands, Ports or Pretincts, or therin he hid, or ≈øhelter them≈øelves; Then that Common wealth which ≈øhall receuve ≈øuch Letters, „Äà‚óä‚óä„Äâ which ≈øuch notice ≈øhall be giuen, and declaration made concerning ≈øuch Rebels, Enemies or Fugitives, ≈øhall within the ≈øpare of twenty eight daies to be reckoned immediately from the day of the afore≈øaid notice given, charge and command ≈øuch Enemy or Enemies. Rebel or Rebels, Fugitive or Fugitives to withdraw and depart out of their Iuri≈ødictions, Territories, Dominions, Lands, and Precinets, and every of them. And if any ≈øuch Enemy, Rebel or Fugitive ≈øhall not withdraw and depart, as afore≈øaid within the ≈øpare of fifteen daies after ≈øuch charge and command given, That he or they ≈øhall be puni≈øhed with death and lo≈øs of Land and Goods.

XI. That no Rebel or Declared Enemy of the Common-wealth of England, ≈øhall be received into any of the Ca≈øtles, Towns, Ports, Creeks, or other places privileged, or not privileged, which any per≈øon of what degree and quality ≈øoever he be, or ≈øhall be, hath, or hereafter ≈øhall have and po≈ø≈øe≈øs by any Citie what≈øoever, within the Dominions and Iuri≈ødictions of the United Provinces; nor ≈øhall be ≈øuffered by any per≈øon of what degree and quality ≈øoever to be received thereinto, or abide therein. Neither ≈øhall the Lords the States General of the United Provinces, permit or ≈øuffer in any of the places afore≈øaid, any a≈øsi≈øtance, coun≈øel, or favor, in Ships, Men, Money, Uictuals, or in any other manner to be given by any per≈øon, of what degree and quality ≈øoever to any ≈øuch Rebel, or declared Enemy, but ≈øhall openly, and e ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ prohibite and hinder the ≈øame. And if any per≈øon or per≈øons of what degree and quality ≈øoever living or remaining within the Iuri≈ødictions of the United Provinces, or under their power, do to the contrary hereof: Then all & ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ery ≈øuch per≈øon and per≈øons ≈øo doing; as afore≈øaid, ≈øhall for their re≈øpective lives, forfeit and lo≈øe all ≈øuch Ca≈øtles, Towns, Uillages, Lands, and other places, which they or any of them ≈øhall at ≈øuch time have or pretend to have, by any Title what≈øoever. And likewi≈øe that no Rebel or declared Enemy of the States of the United Provinces ≈øhal be ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ved into any of the Ca≈øtles, Towns, Ports, or other places privileged, or not privileged, which any per≈øon or per≈øons of what degree
or quality ≈øoever he or they be, have or ≈øhall have, hold or po≈ø≈øe≈øs within the Common-wealth of England, or Dominions thereof, by any title what≈øoever; nor be ≈øuffered by any per≈øon or per≈øons to be received thereinto or abide therein. Neither ≈øhall the Common-wealth of England, permit or ≈øuffer, in any of the places afore≈øaid, any coun≈øel, a≈øsi≈øtance or favor in Ships, Men, Mony, Uictuals, or in any other manner to be given by any ≈øuch per≈øon or per≈øons of what degree or quality ≈øoever he or they be, to any ≈øuch Rebel or declared Enemy, but ≈øhall openly and expre≈øly prohibite and hinder the ≈øame. And if any of the people of the Common-wealth of England, or under their power, ≈øhall do or attempt any thing to the contrary hereof: That every ≈øuch per≈øon or per≈øons, ≈øhall for their re≈øpective lives, forfeit and lo≈øe all ≈øuch Ca≈øtles, Towns, Uillages, Lands and other places, which they or any of them ≈øhall at ≈øuch time have or pretend to have, by any Title what≈øoever.

XII. That the Common-wealth of England, and the People and Inhabitants thereof, and the ≈øaid United Provinces, and the Subjects and Inhabitants thereof, of what quality or condition ≈øoever they be, ≈øhall be bound to treat each other on both ≈øides with all Love and Friend≈øhip: That they may come by Water or by Land, into each others Lands, Towns, or Uillages, walled or unwalled, fortified or unfortified; their Havens, and all their re≈øpective Dominions in Europe with freedom and ≈øecurity, and in them remain and continue
as long as they plea≈øe, and there without hinderance buy Uictuals for their nece≈ø≈øary u≈øe. And may al≈øo Trade and Traffique, and have commerce in any Goods or Commodities they plea≈øe, and the ≈øame bring in and carry out at their plea≈øures, paying always the Cu≈øtoms that ≈øhall be ≈øetled, and ≈øaving always all and ≈øingular the Laws and Ordinances of either Common-wealth re≈øpectively. Yet ≈øo that the People and inhabitants of either, u≈øing Commerce in the Countries and Dominions each of other, ≈øhall not be con≈øtrained to pay any greater Cu≈øtoms, Tolls, or Tributes then according to ≈øuch proportion as other Strangers exerci≈øing Commerce in the ≈øame places pay.

XIII. That the Ships and Ue≈ø≈øels of the ≈øaid United Provinces, as well Men of War as others meeting with any of the Ships of War of this Common-wealth in the Briti≈øh Seas ≈øhall ≈øtrike their Flag and lower their Top-≈øail in ≈øuch manner as hath ever been at any time practi≈øed heretofore under any former Government.

XIV. Item, for the greater freedom of Commerce and Navigation, it is agreed, That neither of the ≈øaid Common-wealths ≈øhall receive into any of their Havens, Cities or Towns, or pernut, or ≈øuffer that any of the People or Inhabitants of either of them re≈øpectively
do receive, keep, harbor or give any a≈øsi≈øtance or relief unto any Pirats or Sea Robers, but ≈øhall cau≈øe both the ≈øaid Pirates and Robers, and al≈øo their Receivers, Concealers and A≈øsi≈øtants to be pro≈øecuted, apprehended, and condignly puni≈øhed, for terror to others. And all Ships, Goods and Merchandize, by them Piratically taken, and brought into the Ports of either State, that ≈øhall be found in being yea, though they have been ≈øold, ≈øhall be re≈øtored to the right Owners, or made good to them, or ≈øuch as have their Letters of Attorney or Procuration to claim the ≈øame; due proof of the Proprietors being fir≈øt made in the Court of Admiralty according to Law.

XV. That if either the Common-wealths of England, or the United Provinces of the Low-Countries ≈øhall hereafter make any Treaty of Amity, Alliance or Friend≈øhip with any other Common-wealth Princes, or States, the one ≈øhall comprehend the other, and the Dominions therein, if they ≈øhall de≈øire to be comprehended: And of all ≈øuch Treaties each ≈øhall be bound to give notice to the other.

XVI. That if it ≈øhall happen that during the Amity, Confederation and Alliance, any thing ≈øhall be acted or attempted by any of the People or Inhabitants of either of the ≈øaid Parties again≈øt this Treaty, or any part thereof, either by Land or Sea, or other waters, this Amity, Confederation & Alliance between the ≈øaid Common-wealths
≈øhal not be herby interrupted or broken off, but ≈øhal continu & remain in its ful & whole power only in ≈øuch ca≈øe tho≈øe particular per≈øons, who have offended again≈øt the ≈øaid Treaty, ≈øhall be puni≈øhed and no other, And that ju≈øtice ≈øhall be done, & ≈øatisfaction made to all per≈øons concerned within twelve months after demand thereof made, upon all ≈øuch per≈øons who ≈øhall have don any thing again≈øt this Treaty, by Land or Sea, or other waters in any part of Europe, or any place within the ≈øtraights of Gibralter, or in America, or upon the Coa≈øts of Africk, or in any Lands, I≈ølands, Seas, Creeks, Bayes, Ribers, or any other places on this ≈øide the Cape of Good-Hope. And in all places what≈øoever as afore≈øaid, beyond the ≈øaid Cape, within 18. months next after demand of Iu≈øtice, ≈øhall ≈øo as afore≈øaid be made: And in ca≈øe the per≈øons ≈øo as afore≈øaid offending, ≈øhall not appear and ≈øubmit them≈øelves to ju≈øtice, and make ≈øatisfaction within the terms re≈øpectively here before limited, the ≈øaid per≈øons ≈øhall be declared Enemies to both Commonwealths, and their E≈øtates, Goods, and effects what≈øoever, ≈øhall be confi≈øcate and employed to a due and full ≈øatisfaction for the wrongs by them done, and their per≈øons be liable to ≈øuch further puni≈øhment, when they ≈øhall come within the power of either State, as the quality of their offence ≈øhall de≈øerve.

XVII. That the people of the Commonwealth of England & the DominioÃÑs thereof, may freely unmole≈øted, & ≈øecurely travel in & through the Countries, & ≈øingular the Dominions of the
united Provinces in Europe, by land or by water, to any place in them, or beyond them, and pa≈øs by any of their Towns, Gari≈øons, or Forts in any places within the Netherlands what≈øoever, or ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ re, in any of their Dominions in Europe, to follow their Traffique in all places there: as al≈øo their Facters and Servants armed or unarmed; but if armed, not above forty men in Company, as well without as with their Goods and Merchandizes whither they plea≈øe. And likewi≈øe the people and Inhabitants of the united Provinces of the Netherlands may enjoy the ≈øame liberties in all the Dominions of the Commonwealth of England in Europe. They and either of them ob≈øerving and conforming in ≈øuch their Trade and traffique to the Laws and Ordinances of each Commonwealth re≈øpectively.

XVIII. Item, Agreed, That if the Merchant Ships belonging to the people and ≈øubjects of our or the other ≈øide, ≈øhall through tempe≈øt, Pirates, or any other nece≈ø≈øity, be driven into Port within the Dominions of either, it ≈øhall be free for them to depart thence ≈øecurely with their Ships and Merchandize, without payment of any Cu≈øtoms or other duties, provided they break not bulk, or expo≈øe any thing to ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ le, nor ≈øhall they be ≈øubjected to any trouble or vi≈øitation, ≈øo be it they receive not aboard any per≈øons or goods, nor ≈øhall do any thing contrary to the Laws, Statutes & Cu≈øtoms of that place „Äà‚óä‚óä‚óä„Äâ into Port as afore≈øaid.

XIX. That the Merchants, Ma≈øters, Pilots, or Mariners of either Commonwealth, their Ships, Goods, Wares, and Merchandizes, ≈øhall not be ≈øeized or arre≈øted in the Lands, Ports, Havens, and Rivers of the other, by vertue of any general or particular Command, for any warlike or other ≈øervice, except upon inevitable nece≈ø≈øity, and upon ju≈øt ≈øatisfaction for the ≈øame, provided that hereby ≈øhall not be excluded the Arre≈øts and ≈øeizures in the ordinary way of Law & ju≈øtice of each Commonwealth re≈øpectively.

XX. That the Merchants on both ≈øides their Factors & Servants, as al≈øo the Shipma≈øters and other Seafaring men may as wel traveling and returning by Ships over the Seas and other waters, as in the Havens of each other, and going on ≈øhoare, carry and u≈øe for the defence of them≈øelves and their Goods, all ≈øorts of Arms for defence and offence; But being come to their ≈øeveral Lodgings or Inns, they ≈øhal lay down their Arms there, and ≈øo leave them til they go again to the ≈øhip, or on board.

XXI. That the men of War of either Common-wealth, meeting or overtaking any Merchant ≈øhip or ≈øhips at Sea, belonging to the other, or to the people or Inhabitants thereof, holding both one cour≈øe, or going both one way, ≈øhall be bound, ≈øo long as they keep one cour≈øe together, to take them under their protection, and to defend them again≈øt all and every that ≈øhall attempt upon them.

XXII. That if any Ship or Ships of the People or Inhabitants of either Commonwealth, or of a Ne ‚Ä¢ ter, ≈øhall be taken in the Havens of either vp any third party, being none of the people or Inhabitants of either Common-wealth; They, in or from who≈øe Havens and Liberties the ≈øaid ≈øhips ≈øhall be taken, ≈øhall be bound together with the other party, to endeavor that the ≈øaid taken ≈øhip or ≈øhips may be followed, brought back, and re≈øtored to the Owners, but all at the charges of the proprietors or intere≈ø≈øed.

XXIII. That Searchers and other Officers of that nature on both parts, ≈øhall, in execution of their Offices, regulate them≈øelves according to the Laws of each Commonwealth re≈øpectively, and ≈øhall not leavy on take more than they are allowed by their Commi≈ø≈øion or In≈øtructions.

XXIV. That in ca≈øe any wrong or injury be done by either Commonwealth, or by the people or Inhabitants thereof, again≈øt the people or Inhabitants of the other, either again≈øt any the Articles of this Treaty, or again≈øt Common right, there ≈øhall yet no Letters of Repr ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ Mark or Counter-mark, be granted by the one or the other Commonwealth, till fir≈øt Iu≈øtice be there ≈øought in the ordinary cour≈øe of Law‚ñ™ and in ca≈øe that Iu≈øtice be there revoked or delayed, then, that Demand be made thereof from the „Äà‚óä„Äâ power of the Commonwealth, who≈øe People or Inhabitants
have ≈øuffered wrong, or from ≈øuch as the ≈øuprenie power ≈øhall depute, to that Common-wealth where Iu≈øtice is as afore≈øaid denied, or delaid, or to ≈øuch power as ≈øhall bee by them appointed to receiv ≈øuch Demands, that all ≈øuch differences may bee compo≈øed amicably, or in the ordinary cour≈ø of Law. But if there ≈øhall bee yet delay, and that Iu≈øtice bee not don, nor ≈øati≈øfaction given within three moneths after ≈øuch Demand made, that then Letters of Reprizall, Marque or Countermarque may bee granted.

XXV. That all per≈øons on either ≈øide that ≈øhall go out to Sea upon particular Commi≈ø≈øions ≈øhal bee bound before they take out their Commi≈ø≈øions to put in good & ≈øufficient Security by re≈øpon≈øible Men not of the Ships Company, before the Iudges of the Court whence the ≈øaid Commi≈ø≈øion is i≈ø≈øued, that they ≈øhall do no wrong or injury to the People or Inhabitants of either ≈øide.

XXVI.
